utterances: South Korea hopes North Korea will do the same, though we should note North Korea's speakers were already far less audible.
They've had technical issues.
Nat Kretchun studies information flow into and within North Korea.
He says while these counter-broadcasts have been used on and off for decades, they're more of a political tool than a means for reaching a wide population.
The only people on either side that are in broadcast reach are forward-deployed soldiers.
And the kind of content that these things broadcast generally are not going to change the mind of soldiers on the frontlines.
Lipsy and her husband are in a unique position.
The economic downturn that's causing their jewelry store to suffer is actually helping their other business.
They also guide jewelers through the process of closing up shop.
We'll probably be OK because we have the other business that feeds into this one.
We all just need to wait this out.
If somebody wanted to take over my lease right now, I'd be on the road doing the consulting work.
And then, when it would all come back around, we'd start all over again.
(Soundbite of people talking)
But not everyone is suffering.
Herbert Zinger(ph) and his wife own the baklava factory which sells baked goodies nearby.
Our business is going up.
Going up?
We are surprised, but our business is much, much more better than last year.
Well, you are the first person I think I've heard to say that...
Yeah, I'm surprised myself, and knock on wood, hopefully, it stays this way.
It might be because the baklava hits the spot.
It's good stuff.
But, Zinger says, it might also be that the family-owned pastry shop across Ventura Boulevard closed three months ago.
For NPR News, I'm Skye Rohde.
This is News and Notes.
I'm Farai Chideya.
Time now for our Africa update.
This week more than 40 African leaders called for free, fair and peaceful elections in Zimbabwe.
Plus we look at Somalia in crisis.
For more, we've got Roxanne Lawson.
She is director of Africa Policy for TransAfrica Forum.
Hi, Roxanne.
Hi, how are you doing today?
I'm doing great.
Let's talk about this run-off election scheduled for next week in Zimbabwe.
Forty African leaders signed an open letter calling for Zimbabwe's presidential run-off to be peaceful and fair.
We're talking about 18 former presidents or prime ministers, two noble laureates, musician Youssou N'Dour, who is also an activist and Archbishop Desmond Tutu.
This as President Mugabe threatens to go to war if the opposition party wins the run-off.
So last week I spoke with Morgan Tsvangirai, the opposition leader, who had this to say about Robert Mugabe.
For me, I think that the first decade of independence, Robert Mugabe was my hero.
I think he deteriorated and I don't know what has made him to transform from a hero to a villain.
And now he is a real tyrant, and I think it is very unfortunate.
What are you hearing from Zimbabweans about the run-off election and what they expect from it?
I'm hearing exactly, I think, what the African leaders in their recent statement have said quite loudly.
Zimbabweans on the ground, civil society is adamant in wanting a free and fair election at the end of next week.
They want the ability to be able to vote.
I heard from one of my colleagues there that even if Zimbabweans have to crawl to the ballot boxes, they will be there and they will cast their ballots.

We also spoke with opposition leader Tsvangirai about the violence that some of his supporters have gone through, including some who have died, some who have been beaten, and he spoke about the young people who - one person said, I can't wait to get better so I can go vote.
Do you think that people who are under physical duress will still put themselves at risk if that's what it takes?
I think they will and they have.
I mean, so many members of civil society in Zimbabwe have not left the country.
They've decided to stay there to fight.
They want to safeguard their democracy.
They want to try to create a government that reflects them and their values.
I think that's really important.
I think that they are very much thinking of the mantel of their parents and grandparents who waged a liberation struggle, and they are resolute.
Also, that they are not going to just - that a vote for the opposition is not just to vote for a vote against Mugabe, but rather is a vote for something in the future.
And that they also will be just as vigilant if the government changes, vigilant in watching their new government, in making sure that they actually uphold their values.
What about the reports that Robert Mugabe is calling for war?
Should that be taken as grandstanding or a serious threat?
I think there are elements of a serious threat in what Robert Mugabe has said.

I think that if you look at the government right now in Zimbabwe, the ZANU-PF government, they way in which they positioned themselves quite strategically in the last couple of weeks, the removing of international aid workers from rural areas in Zimbabwe, not only cuts of aid to some opposition members but it also actually takes away international witnesses to any kind of crimes that may happen in those areas.

I think that that, as well as the kind of arming of the police, of forcing, I think, younger people and the police and military and older people to vote in a certain way, as they did those away ballots last week.
All of those things point towards a very strategic and very purposeful stance that actually is the beginning of a quiet warfare.
I want to move on to East Africa.
Conditions in Somalia are getting worse.
Violence has increased dramatically since a UN peace agreement was signed last week between insurgents and the government.
Now this agreement calls for a three-month truce and withdrawal of Ethiopian troops after a sizeable force of UN peacekeepers are deployed in Somalia.
Do you think that that plan, that truce, is going to work and hold?
Well, I think already it hasn't worked and held.
I think part of the problem is, you know, the rampant number of arms that are in Somalia right now, in the hands of both governments supporting and the opposition, and that's really very problematic.
And 80 percent of the arms that are Somalia have come from the Somali government, the transitional federal government, and many of those arms have come from Ethiopia and from the U.S, via Ethiopia.
I think that's shown us that actually, this ceasefire may not work.
I think also the sticking point is that the need for the African Union to be able to deploy more troops that are currently on the ground.
Right now, only about 2,500 troops from Uganda and Rwanda are on the ground in Somalia, and those numbers need to grow exponentially.
Lieutenant Ross, who's based out of Camp LeJeune in North Carolina, can report something extraordinary to those who remember Marjah from two years ago.
None of his Marines has been shot at in the past six months, so Marjah is relatively secure now.
The key question is this: what happens when the Americans leave?
In the coming weeks, Lieutenant Ross will head home with hundreds of other Marines and something of a skeleton crew will remain to work with Afghan forces.
Can the Afghan army and police take over and keep the peace?
I think so.
I think they want us to leave.
They're ready for it.
That's Lieutenant Colonel Michael Styskal, the top Marine officer in the area.
He stopped by the small American combat outpost not far from the marketplace.
Now, about 3,000 Afghan government forces are helping with Marjah's security, so Colonel Styskal isn't too worried about the Taliban returning.
He worries more about the lack of international help in Marjah from the U.N.
and aid groups that could let the area slide back into chaos.
From the beginning, we put a lot of effort into it.
To fail would be very bad.
Many Afghan officers, both army and police, say the Americans can't leave just yet.
The Americans have the surveillance equipment, the tanks, artillery and aircraft.
The Afghans say they need all that to fight the Taliban.
Marine Colonel Styskal brushes off these requests.
I think they'll do the job with what they have.
They'll fight the way they need to fight.
I don't think the Marjah people and the elders and the government and the security forces here worked so hard for something just to get, you know, let to kind of rot on the vine.
The hundreds of Afghan police in Marjah outnumber the Taliban and the Colonel says their weapons are better.
Back in Marjah's marketplace, a group of men sit on a large raised mat sipping tea and selling vegetables.
Can the Americans leave?
The men in the marketplace think so.
(Through Translator) Yeah, they can leave.
So does Abdullah Jan, the policeman in the bizarre.
He's still at his post just across the street and he's confident enough to tell the Marines that he and his fellow Afghan police can handle whatever comes.
(Through Translator) Yeah.
They're free to go to their home because they have a home, somebody waiting for them.
The new support is good.
Now we can do something for our country.
That may be the greatest measure of success for Marjah, the willingness of men like Abdullah Jan to stay on the job.
Tom Bowman, NPR News, Helmand Province, Afghanistan.
Another story we're following today involves a conflict in Guatemala.
In that country, driving a bus can be lethal.
Corruption, crime and poverty have led to deadly competition among rival bus owners and have also fueled an extortion racket.
Armed gangs demand bribes from the drivers.
Drivers who don't pay up often pay with their lives.
More than 70 drivers have been killed already this year in Guatemala and the problem is especially bad in the capital, Guatemala City.
NPR's Jason Beaubien reports.
(SOUNDBITE OF HORN HONKING)
In Zona Quatro on the northwest edge of Guatemala City, Percida Iguara(ph) is waiting for the Number 70 bus, one day after a driver on the line was assassinated behind the wheel.
Iguara is terrified of the public buses, but she doesn't have a car and she says this is the only way to get around.
(Spanish spoken)
Iguara says the situation on Guatemala's buses is out of control.
(Spanish spoken)
Drivers rent the vehicles by the day and they get to keep whatever proceeds are left after paying for fuel, protection and a meager salary for a fare collector.
The faster you go, the more money you make.
And why stick to your route if you can veer off and poach your rival's passengers?
Or you could literally just kill your competition.
(Spanish spoken)
In addition, local gangs extort protection money or la renta from drivers who pass through their territory.
Twenty-four-year-old Luis Enrique Shava(ph), who has been working as a bus assistant for six years, says drivers are scrounging just to make enough to eat.
But he says drivers can't get away without paying la renta to the local street gangs.
(Spanish spoken)
